**G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u202f3**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 185C, § 3** (Housing Court jurisdiction over landlord-tenant matters) and **G.L. c. 231, § 1** (civil actions for money damages and equitable relief).

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u202f1**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 185C, § 3** (Housing Court jurisdiction over landlord-tenant matters) and **G.L. c. 231, § 1** (civil actions for money damages and equitable relief).

**105 CMR 410.000 et seq.**.proposition: After Defendant failed to make timely repairs, Plaintiff contacted the City of Boston’s Inspectional Services Department, which inspected the Premises and identified violations of the Massachusetts Sanitary Code (**105 CMR 410.000 et seq.**) relating to the water infiltration and other issues.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a7\u202f2A**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct further violated **G.L. c. 239, § 2A** and **G.L. c. 186, § 18**, which protect tenants from retaliatory conduct following reports to governmental authorities.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f18**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct further violated **G.L. c. 239, § 2A** and **G.L. c. 186, § 18**, which protect tenants from retaliatory conduct following reports to governmental authorities.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that persistent water leaks, unhealthy living conditions, and failure to remedy code violations constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion’s main holding concerns whether a lead paint statute violation automatically constitutes a quiet enjoyment violation, but in doing so it expressly characterizes prior quiet enjoyment cases. The court cites Simon v. Solomon and Darmetko as examples where a landlord’s failure to repair defects (including floods and a leaky roof) violated § 14, and it notes that failure to bring and keep an apartment in habitable condition can breach quiet enjoyment. Although this case itself is about lead paint, it reaffirms that persistent water intrusion and unhealthy, unremedied conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that persistent water leaks, unhealthy living conditions, and failure to remedy code violations constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on excessive noise from a bar/lounge operated by another tenant whom the landlord could control. It does not involve water leaks, unhealthy living conditions, or failure to remedy code violations, nor does it state any long‑recognized Massachusetts rule specifically about those types of conditions. While it confirms that serious interference with habitability can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not support the particular proposition about leaks, unhealthy conditions, and code violations.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that persistent water leaks, unhealthy living conditions, and failure to remedy code violations constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions as interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under both the common‑law covenant and G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that “quiet enjoyment” covers serious interferences with the tenancy, ties that to the landlord’s duty to maintain sanitary, watertight premises, and holds Gem liable under § 14 because it allowed repeated flooding that violated sanitary requirements. This directly supports the proposition that persistent water leaks/unhealthy conditions and failure to remedy code violations constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 95.proposition: Additional authority supports Plaintiff’s claim, including *Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (finding breach of quiet enjoyment for repeated flooding); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 23 (2002); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (establishing implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment).
*Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 95.support_reasoning: The opinion does find a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so based on soot contamination and poor maintenance, not “repeated flooding.” The text contains no discussion of flooding or water intrusion as the basis for the quiet enjoyment violation, so citing Dorgan v. Loukas specifically for “repeated flooding” is inaccurate. It is authority for breach of quiet enjoyment from serious habitability defects generally, not for flooding in particular.
*Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 95.relevant_excerpt: “The defendants were also found, with respect to the condition of the apartment, to have violated the implied warranty of habitability (see Boston Housing Authy. v. Hemingway, supra) and the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see c. 186, § 14), but recovery was allowed on c. 93A as covering the ground of the other two claims and being the largest of all. See Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 401 (1982).”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Additional authority supports Plaintiff’s claim, including *Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (finding breach of quiet enjoyment for repeated flooding); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 23 (2002); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (establishing implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition lists Lowery v. Robinson among authorities supporting a tenant’s claim for breach of quiet enjoyment in habitability-type conditions. Lowery squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14, and rejects financial inability to purchase fuel as a defense. That directly supports using Lowery as additional authority for a tenant’s quiet enjoyment claim based on serious habitability defects (here, lack of heat).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously “impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises” … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed “whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.” … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to … damages and counsel fees under § 14.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Additional authority supports Plaintiff’s claim, including *Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (finding breach of quiet enjoyment for repeated flooding); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 23 (2002); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (establishing implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition lists Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth. as additional authority generally supporting a plaintiff’s claim of breach of quiet enjoyment/warranty of habitability, alongside cases involving physical conditions like repeated flooding. This opinion does recognize and apply G.L. c. 186, §14 and holds that pervasive third-party criminal activity, coupled with a landlord’s failure to act, can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, but it expressly rejects expanding the implied warranty of habitability beyond physical defects. Thus, it supports quiet-enjoyment-based claims, not habitability-based ones, and does not fit neatly with the proposition’s broader grouping of habitability/quiet-enjoyment precedents for conditions like flooding.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services. … We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 2.proposition: Additional authority supports Plaintiff’s claim, including *Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (finding breach of quiet enjoyment for repeated flooding); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 23 (2002); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (establishing implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment).
*Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 2.support_reasoning: The proposition lists Carter v. Seto as additional authority for a tenant’s claim involving breach of quiet enjoyment / implied warranty of habitability. Carter v. Seto, however, is an insurance/subrogation and summary judgment case about duplicate recovery for automobile property damage; it does not involve landlord‑tenant law, quiet enjoyment, habitability, or housing conditions. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
*Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 2.relevant_excerpt: This is a Dist/Mun. Cts. R. A. D. A, Rule 8B, appeal by the defendant-insured of summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff-insurer on its claim for reimbursement for insurance payments made to the defendant for the total loss of her automobile. The plaintiff contended that the defendant obtained a second payment for the same loss in the settlement of an independent civil action she subsequently brought against the tortfeasor.

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Additional authority supports Plaintiff’s claim, including *Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (finding breach of quiet enjoyment for repeated flooding); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 23 (2002); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (establishing implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The proposition lists Haddad v. Gonzalez among authorities supporting a tenant’s claim regarding quiet enjoyment and habitability, including cases on repeated flooding and related conditions. While Haddad does involve a tenant’s counterclaims for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and breach of quiet enjoyment, the SJC’s opinion actually resolves questions about (1) recusal, (2) whether emotional distress damages are recoverable and multipliable under Chapter 93A, and (3) how to measure habitability damages. It does not contain any substantive discussion or doctrinal development of quiet enjoyment itself, nor does it concern repeated flooding. Thus, it is not accurate authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition described.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt:
“After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action… the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14… After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims… We now affirm…

3. Measure of damages for breach of warranty of habitability. On the counterclaim of Gonzalez for breach of warranty of habitability, the judge concluded that Gonzalez was entitled to the difference between the actual value of the apartment in its defective condition and the fair market value of the apartment… The judge applied the correct measure of damages.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Additional authority supports Plaintiff’s claim, including *Dorgan v. Loukas*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (finding breach of quiet enjoyment for repeated flooding); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Carter v. Seto*, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 23 (2002); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (establishing implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The proposition relies on Hemingway as authority that Massachusetts recognizes an implied warranty of habitability closely related to quiet enjoyment. In this concurring/dissenting opinion, Justice Quirico expressly agrees that the court is abandoning the old rule of no implied fitness and adopting a new rule making the landlord’s repair/maintenance obligation and the tenant’s rent obligation mutually interdependent, grounded in statutory housing standards. Although he disagrees with the majority’s precise formulation of an open‑ended ‘implied warranty of habitability,’ he accepts the core shift to an implied habitability obligation tied to minimum code standards, which is the legal principle for which the case is commonly cited.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes…prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”}
